philosophers_schema.name: Avestura
philosophers_schema.description: Author of this blog post and personal reference for understanding the ideas of great philosophers.

philosophers_schema.name: Laozi
philosophers_schema.description: Author of Daodejing, known for his idea of Wu Wei (inaction).

philosophers_schema.name: Confucius
philosophers_schema.description: Known as the most impactful teacher in China, author of Analects.

philosophers_schema.name: Siddhartha Gautama (Buddha)
philosophers_schema.description: Taught to overcome Dukkha with everyday life, introduced Sila and Samadhi practices.

philosophers_schema.name: Diotima of Mantinea
philosophers_schema.description: Inspired Socrates, gave the basics of Platonic love concept.

philosophers_schema.name: Socrates
philosophers_schema.description: Described as 'The Gadfly of Athens', known for his method of questioning and ideas like 'I know that I know nothing'.

philosophers_schema.name: Diogenes of Sinope
philosophers_schema.description: Famous for challenging traditions in a violent and insulting way, and the austerity and simplicity of his life based on Cynic philosophy.

philosophers_schema.name: Plato
philosophers_schema.description: One of the most impactful philosophers in Western philosophy, known for his Theory of Forms and ideas like 'The Republic'.

philosophers_schema.name: Aristotle
philosophers_schema.description: Had a natural approach to philosophy, interested in biology and the study of sea creatures.

philosophers_schema.name: Mencius
philosophers_schema.description: One of the most notable Confucianist philosophers, believed that human nature is righteous and humane.

philosophers_schema.name: Master Zhuang
philosophers_schema.description: Had a simple life in nature far from society, consistent with his Taoist beliefs.

philosophers_schema.name: Epicurus
philosophers_schema.description: Believed that the goal of life is to live happily and with pleasure, recommended moderate pleasure and peace of mind.

philosophers_schema.name: Marcus Aurelius
philosophers_schema.description: A Stoic philosopher who became the Roman emperor at 40, known for his 'Meditations' and ideas like 'Virtue is the only good'.

philosophers_schema.name: Nagarjuna
philosophers_schema.description: One of the most important and impactful Buddhist philosophers, founded Madhyamaka or 'The Middle Way' school.

philosophers_schema.name: Augustine of Hippo
philosophers_schema.description: A theologian and philosopher who was against slavery and boldly wrote a letter urging the emperor to set up a new law.

philosophers_schema.name: Hypatia
philosophers_schema.description: One of the most famous astronomers and mathematicians of her time, as well as a prominent Neoplatonic teacher and philosopher.

philosophers_schema.name: Boethius
philosophers_schema.description: One of the greatest philosophers of the classical period, wrote 'On the Consolation of Philosophy' in prison.

philosophers_schema.name: Ibn Sina (Avicenna)
philosophers_schema.description: A polymath author of 'The Book of Healing' and 'The Canon of Medicine' encyclopedias.

philosophers_schema.name: Anselm
philosophers_schema.description: Known as the father of the scholastic tradition, believed that faith is more valuable than logic.

philosophers_schema.name: Hildegard of Bingen
philosophers_schema.description: One of the most impactful composer, philosopher, mystic, and medical writer of the Middle Ages.

philosophers_schema.name: Ibn Rushd (Averroes)
philosophers_schema.description: Combined Greek and Islamic thoughts, proposed the 'unity of the intellect' philosophical theory.

philosophers_schema.name: Zhu Xi
philosophers_schema.description: Created an impactful philosophical system which is known as Neo-Confucianism.

philosophers_schema.name: Moses Maimonides
philosophers_schema.description: Believed that God's nature will always remain unknown because it is beyond human understanding.

philosophers_schema.name: Albertus Magnus
philosophers_schema.description: Combined Aristotle's thoughts with Christian teachings.

philosophers_schema.name: Thomas Aquinas
philosophers_schema.description: Believed that mocking the judgment of reason is mocking the judgment of God, and there is no conflict between philosophy and reason with church beliefs.

philosophers_schema.name: William of Ockham
philosophers_schema.description: Believed that God can not be known directly, and God will always be incomprehensible to mankind.

philosophers_schema.name: Desiderius Erasmus
philosophers_schema.description: A Humanist philosopher who believed in the importance of humanism.

philosophers_schema.name: Niccolo Machiavelli
philosophers_schema.description: Believed that sometimes oppression is better than mercy, and baseness is better than forgiveness.

philosophers_schema.name: Michel de Montaigne
philosophers_schema.description: Popularized essay-writing as a literary genre.

philosophers_schema.name: Francis Bacon
philosophers_schema.description: Believed in the importance of empirical research and the use of reason to improve human life.

philosophers_schema.name: Thomas Hobbes
philosophers_schema.description: Believed that only authoritarian governments can save mankind from the evil consequences of its human nature.

philosophers_schema.name: René Descartes
philosophers_schema.description: Founded the view of rationalism and believed that reason is the key to understanding the universe.

philosophers_schema.name: Blaise Pascal
philosophers_schema.description: Propagated a religious doctrine that taught the experience of God through the heart rather than through reason.

philosophers_schema.name: Baruch Spinoza
philosophers_schema.description: Believed in absolute monism and that mind and body are only transformations of a single substance, the substance that creates the world and that is God.

philosophers_schema.name: John Locke
philosophers_schema.description: Established the basis of political liberalism and philosophical empiricism.

philosophers_schema.name: Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
philosophers_schema.description: Invented differential and integral calculus and believed in the concept of monads as fundamental elements of existence.

philosophers_schema.name: Juana Inés de la Cruz
philosophers_schema.description: A poet, scholar, dramatist, and a nun who devoted her life to scientific and philosophical studies and the creation of literary works.

philosophers_schema.name: George Berkeley
philosophers_schema.description: Proposed the concept of Subjective Idealism and believed that material objects exist only in the form of perception.

philosophers_schema.name: Voltaire
philosophers_schema.description: A key figure of the rationalism of the Age of Enlightenment and one of the founders of the modern liberal tradition.
